abstract.p: The Swiss housing market is characterised by an extraordinarily low vacancy rate, generally in the vicinity of 1 per cent. Is the Swiss housing market permanently in a condition of severe shortage? This paper uses both a standard non-accelerating rent inflation rate of vacancy approach and a new perception-based approach to answer this question. The available evidence confirms that a vacancy rate of 1–1.5 per cent is indeed sufficient for the Swiss housing market to be in equilibrium, provided only dwellings that are not only unoccupied but also actually offered for rent or purchase are counted (which makes this rate not easily comparable with other countries). The standard equilibrium vacancy rate approach suggests that even lower rates are sufficient in more densely built places whereas the approach based on perceptions makes no difference. This suggests that the dwellings listed by people who wish to move reduce the pressure on rents but not the feeling of housing shortage.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Obvious symptoms of housing shortage are poor housing conditions, unaffordable housing and a low vacancy rate. This paper focuses on the last symptom, mainly because our terrain of analysis is a housing market—that of Switzerland—in which the population clearly enjoys high housing comfort at affordable prices (Thalmann, 1999), but vacancy rates are extraordinarily low. There are households that live in crowded conditions, in poorly maintained buildings or with excessive exposure to environmental nuisances (mainly noise). However, only 9 per cent of all dwellings do not have central heating and only 1 per cent do not have running hot water (2000 census). Double-glazed windows, balconies and storage rooms are standard equipment even for rental flats. The mean size of dwellings was 106 square metres in 2000 for households counting on average 2.3 persons. Tenants spend on average 19 per cent of their gross income on housing (including heating and electricity) and homeowners 13 per cent.1 These are indices of high yet affordable housing standards in international comparison.

On the other hand, the national housing vacancy rate, the ratio of dwellings offered for rent or owner-occupation to the total housing stock,2 has remained below 1.5 per cent since 2000 and even below 1.1 per cent since 2003.3 In the past 60 years, the vacancy rate has never exceeded 2 per cent. Even for rental housing alone, the vacancy rate has been close to 1.5 per cent since 2002. In the European Union, only The Netherlands (1.5 per cent in 2009) and Sweden (1.7 per cent in 2009) report comparably low vacancy rates for conventional dwellings (Dol and Haffner, 2010, table 3.4). Switzerland’s neighbours are used to much higher vacancy rates—Austria: 8.4 per cent (2001, Statistik Austria), France: 6.0 per cent (2008, Insee), Germany: 8.0 per cent (2006, Statistisches Bundesamt Deutschland). In the US, the rental housing vacancy rate has been varying around 10 per cent since 2003 (US Census Bureau).4 Note, however, that these figures rest on quite different definitions of vacant housing, which makes them hardly comparable.

In Switzerland, vacant dwellings are precisely defined as flats or single-family houses that satisfy the following conditions: they are fit for full-year habitation, unoccupied and proposed for rent, formally or informally, for at least three months or for purchase (no contract yet) on the day of the annual survey, 1 June. They can be furnished or not. They can even be holiday homes or second residences.5 This definition tries to count the dwellings that are really offered and available at a particular date. Unoccupied dwellings that do not satisfy these conditions are called empty. They are typically in the process of demolition or renovation or their owners are hoarding them. In areas where both vacant and empty dwellings are counted, the numbers are of the same magnitude. Data from the large sample of rental housing properties in the Swiss Property Benchmark indicate that the share of foregone rental income due to vacancies is even less than the vacancy rate. Finally, careful verification of the statistics has shown that they are accurate in the aggregate, in spite of misclassifications and omissions at the local level (Sager, 2006).

That Switzerland can be content with low vacancy rates is suggested by the fact that rent regulation was based in the 1980s on a law that applied only to markets where the vacancy rate was below 1.5 per cent. Some cantons still use that threshold for their housing policy. In comparison, a rule of thumb in the US, which is also used for policy guidance, is that the rental market is in equilibrium with a vacancy rate of 5 per cent (Belsky, 1992). So, is 1.5 per cent really sufficient for the Swiss housing market?

There is no consensus on the vacancy rate necessary for the market to be in equilibrium. It is obviously not zero, even when only dwellings actually offered for rent or purchase are counted (excluding dwellings in dereliction or transformation). When a snapshot of the market is taken at any point in time, there are always some dwellings currently unoccupied, just as there are always some people between two jobs. The classical test for an excessively low vacancy rate is the pressure it exerts on rents. Section 2 applies that approach to test whether vacancy rates in the 1–1.5 per cent range could be compatible with market equilibrium.

One could also look at housing mobility under the assumption that housing shortage constrains it. Indeed, this is often the main concern associated with housing shortage. The problem with this approach is that it is hard to define a ‘natural’ level of mobility, with which actual mobility could be compared. Nevertheless, it is instructive to observe housing mobility in Switzerland in regard of its very low vacancy rate.

Between June 2009 and June 2010, when the vacancy rate was near 0.9 per cent, about 493 000 dwellings experienced a change of tenant or owner-occupant, or about 12.7 per cent of the housing stock (calculations of Zurich Cantonal Bank). The contrast between a low vacancy rate and sizeable mobility is even more striking in the city of Zurich, the largest Swiss city with a population of 370 000 in 2007. It counted only 180 vacant dwellings offered for rent (none for sale) on 1 June 2007, or 0.09 per cent of the stock. Nevertheless, 46 551 persons moved into the city in that year and 42 108 changed their address within the city. Only 2263 new dwellings were added to the housing stock (for 591 dwellings demolished), which did not facilitate mobility very much. Rather more important, 40 437 persons left the city and 3480 died. Altogether, there were 130 000 movements of persons for a population of 377 000 (whereby some may have moved several times).6

Mobility is facilitated by the fact that rental contracts are generally terminated on four co-ordinated dates, at the end of each quarter. The rental contract can, however, provide for other termination dates, usually the end of a month. Thus, 49 per cent of all changes of address in the City of Zurich between 1994 and 2007 were registered on the first day of a month and 22 per cent on the first day of a quarter.7 Tenants may only cancel their lease and move out on another date than the contractual or usual date without penalty if they propose a replacement tenant. This protects the landlord more than is common in other countries. On the other hand, with discrete moving dates essentially three months apart, it can be costly for landlords to miss those dates with their vacant dwellings, so they would not take that risk by demanding above-market rents. Furthermore, it is increasingly common for tenants to pay rent for two dwellings during a month or two while they move from one to the other. When all moving tenants move simultaneously on the same dates or they pay the rent for the apartment they vacate until a new tenant moves in, there need not be any vacant dwellings at all, at least based on the narrow Swiss definition of unoccupied dwellings offered for rent or sale and immediately available!

The fact that high mobility is compatible with very low vacancy rates should remind us that the vacancy rate does not measure housing supply. Indeed, the vast majority of dwellings are proposed for rent while still occupied. They see a change of tenant without going through a stage of vacancy. Under Swiss conditions, the share of (occupied) dwellings offered on the market at any time might be a better indicator of the choices open for moving households than the share of vacant dwellings. Unfortunately, there exists no statistic for that, which is easy to understand considering the number of listing services. Multiple listing services not only complicate the collection of the data but create a great risk of double counting.

The empirical work on estimating the equilibrium vacancy rate is still far from a consensus on how to measure it and shows wide variability across estimators and cities. As a result, Belsky (1992) called for alternative measures of housing shortage for policy guidance. After estimating standard EVRs in section 2, with a discussion in section 3 and the estimation of regional EVRs in section 4, this paper proposes an alternative route in section 5, which uses a survey of tenants and homeowners about their housing conditions and their perceptions of the housing market. In particular, they were asked how severe they considered housing shortage to be in the area in which they live. Examining how their responses are related to the statistical vacancy rate in section 6 will allow computing vacancy rates at which housing shortage is seen as small. Section 7 concludes.

sec.title: 2. Estimating the Equilibrium Vacancy Rate
sec.p: Blank and Winnick (1953) and Smith (1974) defined the concept of a ‘natural’ or ‘equilibrium’ vacancy rate (EVR), at which there is no upward or downward pressure on rents.8 A higher vacancy rate forces landlords to slow down rent growth, possibly even to reduce their rents. The EVR can be estimated with an equation of the form

The percentage rate change in rents, deflated by inflation, is related to the excess of the vacancy rate over the EVR. A trend in real rents is generally assumed away (

), so that the EVR can readily be extracted from the estimated constant9

This simple model can be interpreted as an empirical reduced form of rent inflation, as in Rosen and Smith (1983). It resembles the Phillips curve that regresses inflation on the output gap or the Kuznets curve that regresses a measure of income inequality on mean per capita income. It assumes no feedback of the change in rents on the vacancy rate and no dynamic effects.

Tse and MacGregor (1999) estimate a somewhat different model where the real percentage change in rents is a linear function of the previous year’s vacancy rate and the previous year’s change in rents. The time-lag and the presence of the lagged dependent variable result from three assumptions: the current change in rents is equal to the previous year’s plus a partial adjustment to the difference between that and the change in rents expected for this year; the latter is proportional to the difference between the EVR and the vacancy rate expected for this year; the latter is equal to the previous year’s vacancy rate plus a partial adjustment to the difference between it and the EVR. We renounce using lagged variables because of the great smoothness in the vacancy rate and because we believe that market actors are able to perceive the current tightness of the market even before the statistics are yet published.10

There are two rent indices and two vacancy rates available in Switzerland for estimating equation (1). One rent index measures the average change in rents for all dwellings and is used as a component of the consumer price index (CPI). It moves very smoothly and closely to the CPI, which can easily be explained by the inertia in rental contracts (even though long-term contracts are very rare in the Swiss housing market, so that rents can be adjusted every three months) and second-generation rent regulation, which ties rents to costs and protects them from market tensions.11 The second rent index is based on a large survey of advertisement listings for new or pre-rented dwellings and measures the evolution of asking rents.12 Since these rents are not tied by rent regulation or any contracts, their index depicts current market conditions much better than the CPI component index. We will therefore use the asking rents index.

As regards the rate of housing vacancy, Statistics Switzerland has reported a general vacancy rate since 1930 and the number of vacant rental dwellings since 1994. It is debatable whether the evolution of rents should depend on the vacancy rate among rental dwellings alone or on that among all dwellings.13 Indeed, it can be argued that many tenants have the alternative to buy property, particularly in a country where two-thirds of households are still tenants, among whom are many medium- and upper-income households. The econometrics will not help because the global vacancy rate and the rental vacancy rate are very closely correlated over the 1994–2010 period for which both are available, with a Pearson correlation coefficient of 0.994. The rental vacancy rate is 0.6 per cent higher than the global vacancy rate, so one would expect the estimated EVRs for the two definitions to differ by the same amount.

Figure 1 plots the percentage change in the real asking rents index against both vacancy rates. The dots for the individual years are connected by lines in order to show the dynamics.14 Visual inspection suggests a global EVR in the area of 1 per cent and a rental EVR in the area of 2 per cent. That is not the end of the story, though. The dots for the years 1993–96 are quite off the mark. And the simple form of equation (1) has also been challenged both on economic and statistical grounds.

caption.p: Real rate of change of asking rents related to total vacancy rate (1971–2010) and rental vacancy rate (1997–2010).

sec.p: A critique of the simple model of equation (1) is that the EVR need not be constant through time (Wheaton and Torto, 1988). Figure 1 shows that a line fitted to the 1971–75 dots would cross the horizontal axis marking zero growth in real rents a little above 0.8 per cent and another line fitted to the 1998–2009 dots would cross it at about 1.3 per cent, so that some trend in the global EVR may be expected and will be added to the model. Another critique, raised particularly by researchers fitting such a model to the office market (Wheaton and Torto, 1994; Hendershott et al., 2002; Mourouzi-Sivitanidou, 2002), notes that there may be inertia in rents, that they may not adjust immediately to the current or lagged vacancy rate.15 This critique does not apply to our data, because fixed-rate rental contracts are extremely rare in the Swiss housing market and the rents we measure are asking rents for dwellings that are or will be vacated. There is no reason for these rents to show any inertia. Nevertheless, Figure 1 suggests some persistence, as the rate of change in real rents drifts along the lines connecting years. Yet it is perfectly possible and much more plausible that these smooth movements are caused by inertia in the vacancy rate. Indeed, the vacancy rate measures the inability of the housing stock to adjust to demand and these two components evolve very slowly indeed.

Finally, equation (1) has been criticised for not being able to explain the level of rents (Hendershott et al., 2002).16 Indeed, one would expect landlords to refer for their asking rents to costs and not only to the excess demand measured by the (contemporaneous) vacancy rate. We will follow that advice and add to model (1) variables measuring production and user costs of housing.

sec.p: The low Durbin–Watson statistic suggests that the model is incomplete. It would be tempting to correct for possible autocorrelation—for instance, by estimating the model in first differences. We shall resist this temptation, however, following the advice of Mizon (1995). Indeed, there is no economic reason to expect autocorrelation in the dependant variable, as already discussed. Incidentally, estimating the model in first differences would make it impossible to identify the EVR. More importantly, inspection of the residuals shows where the diagnosis of autocorrelated residuals comes from (Figure 2). As was to be expected from Figure 1, the model is unable to explain the sharp drop in asking rents from 1993 until 1995, when the vacancy rate was still in the 1–1.4 per cent range. In 1993, user costs and construction prices declined both by 3.8 per cent, but that cannot account for the decrease in asking rents by almost 12 per cent and that problem remains for two more years. This overshooting could be related to a level of public support to housing construction never seen before or again afterwards.

caption.p: Actual and fitted percentage changes in real asking rents.

sec.p: The constant and the coefficient for the vacancy rate in Table 1 imply an EVR of 1.05 per cent, which can be considered as constant over the past 36 years. The simulated standard error is 0.06 per cent. The distribution of EVR is non-normal. The 5 per cent to 95 per cent confidence interval is equal to 0.98 per cent to 1.16 per cent. For a vacancy rate of 0.5 per cent and no change in construction prices or user costs, real asking rents would grow by 6 per cent and for a vacancy rate of 1.5 per cent they would decline by 3 per cent.

There exist a few other econometric estimates of a Swiss EVR. Müller (1984, pp.180–181), used disequilibrium econometrics to estimate an EVR of 0.3 per cent for Basle over the period 1952–82. Sager (2004) first estimated the Rosen and Smith (1983) model regressing real rents on the vacancy rate, to find an EVR of 1.60 per cent for Switzerland for 1985–2003. Using data for the city of Zurich, he estimated EVRs of 0.35 per cent for 1942–2000 and 0.45 per cent for 1984–2000. Next, he applied the Hendershott et al. (2002) approach to the same data to find lower EVRs of 1.16 per cent for Switzerland and 0.26 per cent for Zurich.18 Sager also reports unpublished estimates by Credit Suisse that were performed regionally and used an index of asking rents instead of the general rental price index. For 1974–2002, Credit Suisse found an EVR of 1.43 per cent for Switzerland and EVRs ranging from 0.90 per cent in the Zurich region to 2.09 per cent in western Switzerland (excluding the Lake Geneva region). These results suggest regional variability, with EVRs typically lower in cities and more urbanised regions. (We estimate regional EVRs in section 4.) They also indicate that the EVR depends on the time-period selected, although we found no trend when accounting for costs. Beyond their variability, all these results confirm that EVRs are very low in Switzerland.

sec.title: 3. Explaining the Low EVR
sec.p: There exist many estimates of EVRs for different housing markets, mainly in North American agglomerations. They are all much higher than the 1 per cent just estimated for Switzerland. Thus, recent estimates by Gabriel and Nothaft (2001) for 29 US metropolitan areas in the years 1987–96 range between 4 and 4.5 per cent, which the authors note to be somewhat below other estimates in the literature. Presumably the size and structure of the market (typology of dwellings, proportion of homeownership, etc.) influence the equilibrium vacancy rate, so one would not expect to find exactly the same values in Switzerland, but the differences are striking. What could account for the very low Swiss EVR?

The literature on EVR uses theoretical arguments to explain differences in EVR, some tested in cross-section estimations. They can be grouped into those that relate to the landlords’ strategy and those that relate to the matching process.

Vacancies are to some extent a deliberate choice by landlords waiting for higher bids or for a tenant willing to accept a higher rent (for example, Hendershott and Haurin, 1988; Amy et al., 2000). This strategy is more profitable in opaque markets with a heterogeneous housing stock and population. The option to wait is also more valuable when households are more mobile and demand more volatile (Grenadier, 1995). Waiting has an opportunity cost, however, in the form of foregone rental income, and it is risky. A higher level of rents is thus an important factor to shorten the duration of vacancy (Gabriel and Nothaft, 2001). Different types of landlord may be more or less willing to take risks. Landlords with a small number of units tend to minimise vacancies, while those with many maximise rents (Belsky, 1992). Finally, waiting for a higher bid makes more sense when contracts or rent regulation provide for fixed rents over a long time.

When observing that 57 per cent of all rental dwellings belong to individual landlords (2000 census) and some 14 per cent to non-profit landlords (Kemeny et al., 2005), it is clear that vacancy minimisation is a stronger motive than rent maximisation in Switzerland. As a general matter, investment in rental housing attracts risk-averse or diversifying investors, on which basis, Büttler and Schiltknecht (1985) had concluded that the EVR in Switzerland ought to be lower than in the US. Real interest rates have always been comparatively low in Switzerland, which would lower the opportunity cost of waiting, but this could be offset by the comparatively high leverage of most landlords. Finally, the population is relatively homogeneous and housing markets are small, which facilitates shopping and makes it less attractive to wait for higher-paying tenants. The almost general absence of fixed-rent contracts in the Swiss housing market implies that landlords are not locked when accepting a low bid. Second-generation rent regulation places less of a lid on the escalation of rents for continuing contracts than rent regulation in other countries.19 All in all, the types of landlords and contracts in Switzerland can contribute to explain a low EVR.

The characteristics of the housing stock and the population matter because vacancies express difficulties in matching the two. Greater heterogeneity of either complicates that process, implying that the EVR will tend to be higher. Atypical dwellings are more frequently vacant (Jud and Frew, 1990). The volatility of demand and supply also complicates the matching process. A population that strives to mobility requires a higher EVR (Rosen and Smith, 1983). On the other hand, Gabriel and Nothaft, 2001, found empirically that the EVR is significantly lower with faster population growth, as if it were repeatedly unanticipated and construction continuously failed to accommodate.

Switzerland is small, with three language regions and a dense transport network, so people do not need to move when they change jobs and they are reluctant to move across the country to live with a different language. The small size of the country, the absence of great regional socioeconomic disparities and the generally high standard of its housing stock should also facilitate the matching process. Finally, its relatively open borders and economic prosperity account for many spells of strong population growth. Thus, demographic characteristics and its housing stock also contribute to making a low EVR plausible for Switzerland.

sec.title: 4. Estimating Regional EVR
sec.p: Further evidence can be obtained by looking at regional markets, particularly as local factors have been shown in other contexts to be strong determinants of equilibrium vacancy rates (Grenadier, 1995). Switzerland is commonly divided into seven or eight regions. Indices of asking rents are available for eight regions since 1970. By aggregating cantonal data, it is possible to compute rental housing vacancy rates for those regions, but only since 1999. We estimate a function similar to the one estimated for the whole market: the real rate of change of asking rents in region i and year t is regressed on the corresponding rental vacancy rate VR. Linear equations fit better than semi-log. The constant is related to the equilibrium vacancy rate in each region

The model is estimated as a panel with regional fixed effects as in Gabriel and Nothaft (1988) (their equation 2). Results are shown in Table 2 for models that use either the rental or the total vacancy rate. They are in conformity with the assumptions and show a surprisingly good fit for such a trivial model. The standard errors of the parameter estimates are relatively low. The resulting implicit rental and total EVRs are also shown in Table 2.

sec.p: The total EVRs estimated for each region are clearly different, ranging from a low of about 0.9 per cent to a high of 2 per cent. The rental EVRs are substantially higher, between 1.4 per cent and 3.4 per cent. They are closely inversely correlated with the degree of urbanisation of the region, however, that is measured (correlation coefficient R = −0.84 for the proportion of occupied dwellings in municipalities of more than 10 000 inhabitants in 2000). Significant correlations obtain with other variables related to urbanisation, such as the share of rental housing in 2000 (R = −0.82) or the proportion of dwellings that experienced a change of tenant in 2009/10 (R = −0.56). These results show that more urbanised regions obtain stable rents with lower vacancy rates, which could be explained by higher mobility. Indeed, with high mobility, vacant dwellings represent a small share of housing supply. In other words, rents are kept in check not so much by vacant dwellings as by the continuous supply of dwellings offered for rent without going through vacancies. Data from the main listing service Homegate indicate that rental apartments are listed for as little as 10 days on average in Geneva.

Obviously, low vacancy rates are compatible with stable real rents in Switzerland. This cannot be explained by rent regulation, as we computed EVRs that stabilise asking rents for new contracts, which are essentially regulation free. Rather, the low vacancy rates are signs of a very efficient housing market. Nevertheless, it is difficult to believe that the population is content with such small vacancy rates, which ought to make it harder to find adequate housing. We shall therefore look behind the statistics and ask it directly.

sec.title: 5. Perceptions of the Low Vacancy Rates
sec.p: What is the vacancy rate at which the population would not perceive housing shortage? We call this novel definition of the EVR the perception-based equilibrium vacancy rate or PEVR. In order to estimate it like the standard EVR, one would need a survey that asked an adequate sample of people whether there is housing shortage or not where they live. We would need time-series of these surveys so that, for each region, we could compare the answers with the statistical vacancy rate and find the rate at which some sufficiently high proportion of the sample perceives no shortage. There would be some difficulty in defining that proportion. Furthermore, housing shortage is not a dichotomous state—there are degrees—so the question would have to be phrased and interpreted carefully.

Here, we can only draw on a general household survey administered by the private research institute gfs-zürich in 2009 to 718 persons selected to be representative of the proportions of residents of the German- and French-speaking parts of the country and of urban and rural neighbourhoods. The sample is also representative of gender, age and occupation distributions. Sample proportions of 50 per cent have a confidence interval of +/- 3.8 per cent. In 2009, the national vacancy rate was 0.90 per cent, close to our estimated national aggregate EVR. The survey can therefore be used to test directly whether respondents felt that the market was in equilibrium. They were asked ‘How severe do you consider housing shortage to be in your canton?’, with four possible answers (shares of answers in brackets): ‘there is none’ (8 per cent); ‘it is small’ (44 per cent); ‘it is large’ (35 per cent); and ‘it is very large’ (13 per cent).20 About one half of the respondents perceive a large or very large housing shortage and the other half see no particular problem.

Clearly, there is considerable variation in the perception of housing shortage. At the same time, there is quite some geographical variation in the vacancy rate. There exist data for all the 2600 or so municipalities, but they are extraordinarily volatile given the small numbers. It is therefore more prudent to use the data for the 26 cantons. The cantonal total vacancy rates ranged from 0.22 per cent to 1.89 per cent in 2009. Therefore, it is possible to compare the perceptions of housing shortage by canton with the cantonal vacancy rates, in order to identify the PEVR. The average perception in a canton is computed as the average response of all survey participants in the canton when their responses are coded 0 (no shortage), 1 (small shortage), 2 (large shortage) or 3 (very large shortage). The mean value for all respondents is 1.53, so the perception of housing shortage is rather moderate.

The relationship between the mean perception of housing shortage and the vacancy rates of June 2009 is shown graphically in Figure 3 for the 13 largest cantons, those for which the number of respondents is sufficient for reliable means (at least 20). The correlation coefficient between the two variables is -0.76.

sec.title: 6. Explaining the Perceptions about Market Equilibrium
sec.p: By analogy with the standard EVR approach, we can define the PEVR as the vacancy rate at which mean perceived housing shortage has a ‘stable’ value, which we define as the middle value of 1.5. This value obtains for instance when an equal number of respondents perceive a small and large shortage and when the number of persons who perceive a very large shortage is exactly offset by an equal number who perceive no shortage at all. This definition acknowledges that there will always be people who perceive some housing shortage because they have a hard time finding the dwelling of their dreams. Similarly, the standard EVR approach does not require all rents to be constant, only on average.

As possible determinants of mean perceived housing shortage, we test the vacancy rate in June 2009, rental only and total, several density and urbanisation indicators, the homeownership rate and measures of residential comfort and desired mobility from the survey.

With so few observations, only 13 cantons, it is necessary to be parsimonious with the explanatory variables. In addition, there are significant correlations between some of them, such as among all the density indicators or between these indicators and the proportion of owner-occupied housing or the share of respondents who were looking for a dwelling within the previous year. This must be kept in mind when examining the explanatory variables retained in the final model, as they may also carry into the model the influence of excluded variables with which they are correlated.

The final model is described in Table 3. The quality of the adjustment is excellent with only two explanatory variables—i.e. the logarithm of the vacancy rate and the indicator of residential comfort.21 The signs are as expected: respondents tend to perceive a more severe housing shortage in cantons that have a lower rate of vacancy and poorer coverage of housing needs. No indicator of urbanisation turns out to be significant, not even a principal component grouping all correlated variables. This can be explained to some extent by the fact that mean perceived housing shortage of the city-canton of Basle, which stands out with a very high degree of urbanisation, is very well explained by the other two variables alone.

sec.p: The PEVRs resulting from these estimations are 1.22 per cent when only rental housing is considered and 0.87 per cent when owner-occupied housing is included. They are even lower than the EVR estimated by the standard stable-rents approach. They are quite sensitive to the value of the mean perceived housing shortage that is deemed compatible with market equilibrium, as illustrated in Figure 4. Thus, a PEVR for rental housing of 2 per cent could be justified by defining the equilibrium with mean perceived shortage of 1.35 instead of 1.5.

sec.title: 7. Conclusion
sec.p: Simple statistical comparisons of vacancy rates with the change in (asking) rents across time or regions suggest that, in Switzerland, the market is in equilibrium, in the sense of stable real rents, when the vacancy rate lies between 1 per cent and 1.5 per cent (between 2 per cent and 2.5 per cent when only rental housing is considered). This equilibrium vacancy rate (EVR) varies between regions, being below 1 per cent in the most urbanised regions and reaching 2 per cent in the more rural ones (1.4 per cent and 3.4 per cent respectively for the rental EVR).

Does this economic definition correspond to people’s perception of a market in equilibrium? In order to answer this question, local vacancy rates were compared with people’s stated feeling about housing shortage. Such perceptions can serve for policy guidance if they are not too strongly tainted by personal conditions. The latter’s influence is eliminated by using cantonal averages of perceived housing shortage. We test the link between these mean perceptions and the vacancy rates, taking into account mean housing conditions and homeownership and urbanisation rates, as well as other possible determinants such as desired mobility. The differences in mean shortage perceptions are statistically well explained by the vacancy rates and the difference between actual and needed housing size as an indicator of housing comfort. Inhabitants of cantons with a smaller vacancy rate and lesser coverage of housing needs perceive a higher housing shortage.

Using these observations, it is possible to compute a ‘perception-based equilibrium vacancy rate’ (PEVR), defined as the vacancy rate for which the mean perception of housing shortage lies exactly between small and large (for the average housing comfort). This PEVR takes the value of 1.2 per cent when only rental housing is considered and 0.9 per cent when owner-occupied housing is included. This confirms that very low vacancy rates are compatible in Switzerland not only with stable rents but also with people’s perception of average housing shortage or availability.

The panel estimation of the rent variation equation has shown that EVRs differ significantly between more and less urbanised regions. With a single cross-section of housing shortage perceptions, it is not possible to identify more than a unique PEVR. However, the equation that relates perceived housing shortage to the vacancy rates and a single other determinant—i.e. housing comfort—obtains a very good fit and shows no systematic influence of the degree of urbanisation of the cantons. This suggests that a unique nationwide perception-based EVR is plausible even if the stable-rent EVRs vary. In other words, a more urbanised region will obtain stable rents with a lower vacancy rate than a more rural region, but people in the two regions will require the same vacancy rates to feel the same degree of housing shortage.

The stable-rent EVR is presumably lower in the more urbanised regions because mobility is higher, so that vacant dwellings contribute a smaller share of the total supply of dwellings, as opposed to non-vacant dwellings listed by people who wish to move. Clearly, caution must be exercised in interpreting the absolute level of the vacancy rate in different regions. On the other hand, the absolute level of the vacancy rate is a good predictor of housing shortage perceptions irrespective of the region. An explanation could be that in urban areas the additional listed dwellings are just offset by the higher proportion of people looking for a dwelling and therefore susceptible to feeling the housing shortage.

Nor is there of course anything similar to more generous support for the long-term unemployed or growing social acceptance of unemployment, common explanations for hysteresis in unemployment (Blanchard and Katz, 1997).
